fields.description:
When a Repository is set to update "Never" and the server is restarted the following message is always displayed until a scan now is issued:

"NOTE: this repository is being scanned, some statistics may still be out of date."

This message is not true.  The area _may_ be out of date if there is no method to auto-trigger a Scan Now event.  Most likely the code base the repository is pointing to has not been updated recently.

Case in point:
We have a Perforce Trigger that will cause Fisheye to scan the repository when an change has been submitted.  Projects may be in a 'static' form for weeks on end.   With a weekly reboot, 3 out of 4 weeks end users see the scan message.

The note should only appear when a repository is actually being scanned.
fields.summary: Improve UI:  Better wording: NOTE: this repository is being scanned, some statistics may still be out of date.

fields.description:
Pagination arrows are missing in ie7 (but show in ie8).

example page: http://stella:6060/crucible/browse/FE/trunk/pom.xml#r43137
fields.summary: IE7 doesn't show pagination in file history

fields.description:
Users often complain to admins that the index appears stuck, when actually it is not. 

This is because the large changelog that it is working does not change e.g. "Creating changeset 17 " (the files it is processing under the change log changes, however is only shown in the admin page). 

We should update the fisheye browse page to show a more accurate picture of the status, and make the things that get updated quickly (such as the current file that is being indexed) more prominent then those things that change less frequently such as changeset number, so that users/admin have a better idea of the current status.
fields.summary: Update status both on View Repository List page, and user view (via the fisheye Browse) of the index messages
OutOfMemoryException during scan of Subversion repository containing copies of large directory structures

fields.description:
Cross repository activity streams cause all repositories to be opened which can take a *long* time for huge numbers of repositories (some customers have >1900).

Using the last write time, activity items should be fetched sequentially youngest to oldest and it should break as soon as enough items have been collected and/or a configurable timeout (default to say 10s) is reached. In the case of a timeout print a message to the stream indicating all items were not fetched.
fields.summary: Break early when building cross repository activiy streams
Large text files, with long history can fill up memory

a file is marked as read as soon as i click on it. the majority of the time, I cant say that a file is okay until I see the other files that use it / are used by it.

fields.summary: crucible marks files as read too aggressively

fields.description:
We do edit, review, commit.

We have to upload a patch, but Crucible doesn't show the full context, only the lines it got from the patch file.

It should use the "Index" marker and/or the ---/+++ markers to match the file up to the existing file in the Subversion repository.

e.g. if I upload a patch file with this header
Index: opt/foo
===================================================================
--- opt/foo      (revision 54664)
+++ opt/foo      (working copy)

If I specify the correct SVN repository and branch, it should show full context from revision 54664 when any reviewer clicks on File View->Full Context.
fields.summary: show patch context from repository

{quote}
Occasionally when we try to add files to a review, the file loading indicator spins forever and we see this in the log. This seems to happen to various files, no apparent pattern. Do you know what could cause this? I have seen it happen on different Fisheye repositories, only on large code reviews.

ERROR - /json/cru/EqSys-5/editRevisionsAjax/
java.lang.NullPointerException
at com.cenqua.crucible.revision.managers.DefaultContentManager.getLazyCrucibleRevision(DefaultContentManager.jav
a:363)
at com.cenqua.crucible.util.ReviewCreationHelper.addRevisions(ReviewCreationHelper.java:367)
at com.cenqua.crucible.actions.create.EditRevisionsAjaxAction.addRemoveRepoRev(EditRevisionsAjaxAction.java:280)

fields.description:
Refer to [CRC-1083|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CRC-1083].
{quote}
Some IE7 users recently noticed a bug that only occurs in IE. To replicate, start a code review. Click a line to comment on and type a comment. Then, click the Post button, but immediately after, click another line. After the page refreshes, the comment will be showing up on the last line that was clicked, instead of showing on the line that was highlighted when the Post button was clicked.
{quote}
See the attached screen shot:
- [comment.png|^comment.png]
- [wrong-comment.png|^wrong-comment.png]

However, the problem goes away after the browser is refreshed. This problem is not reproducible in Firefox browser.
fields.summary: Clicking another location in the file view after posting a comment causes comment box to appear on the wrong line in IE7

fields.description:
Reviews only allow a free-text comments area when closing a review.
We're attempting to put Crucible in our workflow so that the Moderator provides a very clear binary "Yes - approved - promote", or "Not approved, new review needed" as an outcome.
1) It forces the moderator to provide that direct clear feedback
2) It would allow appropriate transitions from jira or other automated workflow - i.e. if approved, jira issue could transition states, if not approved, issue could transition back to In Progress, etc.
3) It allows process improvement discussions when looking at reporting data - i.e. what is the review success rate per developer?

I'd propose that this work similar to the defect classifications, in that the administrator can customize the possible states as part of closing/summarizing a review, potentially with a classification of "approved" vs "failed" for different types of feedback.
fields.summary: Summarize should have classifications/outcomes like defects - i.e. "Approved for Promotion" or "Further Changes Needed"

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a permission scheme with some trailing spaces (e.g. 'abc  ')
2. You then can see the empty permission schemes [EditPermissionScheme|^EditPermissionScheme.JPG]
3. When trying to delete it, the message 'Could not find Permission Scheme' is displayed [DeletePermissionScheme|^DeletePermissionScheme.JPG]

As a workaround,
1. Shut down Crucible instance
2. Open up the {{CRUCIBLE_INST/var/data/crudb/crucible.script}} file
3. Locate the permission schemes that is having the problem. For example:

{noformat}
INSERT INTO PERM_SCHEME VALUES(97,'abc  ')
{noformat}

4. Remove the trailing spaces of the permission scheme
5. Save the file and restart the Crucible
6. Navigate to the permission scheme and remove it from the UI
fields.summary: Not able to view the permission scheme if the scheme name contains some trailing spaces

fields.description: We have quite a bit of clojure (http://clojure.org) code in a few of our projects. Our projects are bugtracked by JIRA, code reviewed by crucible and browsed by fisheye. Source code highlighting is essential to code readability during code reviews (crucible) and quick code references (fisheye), but is missing for clojure sources in both fisheye and crucible. Can you please add code highlight support for clojure in crucible and fisheye?
fields.summary: Clojure Code Highlighting

fields.summary: (500) Internal Server Error

fields.description:
User was performing the rtag operation in CVS which relates to labelling the branch in CVS and it was failing with the error 

The server reported an error while performing the "cvs rtag" command.
  src: cvs [rtag aborted]: Could not map memory to RCS archive /mnt/cvs/Fulfill/src/java/projects/feature_manager/dist/featureman.ear,v: Resource temporarily unavailable

Also while performing a commit or an synchronize or a refresh on local workspace, was getting the same error on the same file.

The file in question is big.  

bash-3.00$ ls -l featureman.ear,v
-r--r--r--   1 cvsd     cvsd     268320130 Oct  6 15:50 featureman.ear,v

bash-3.00$ du -h featureman.ear,v
 256M   featureman.ear,v
fields.summary: Big CVS file + Crucible breaks cvs: Could not map memory to RCS archive

fields.description:
The SQL upgrade task produces incorrect results for {{sql/HSQL/upgrade/upgrade_36.sql}} and so all reviews will look like they were created by the first user. 

The bug is in the following: 

{code:sql}insert into new_cru_state_change (select cru_id, cru_time_stamp, cru_superseded, cru_review_id,cru_new_state,
  (SELECT p.cru_user FROM cru_review_participant p WHERE cru_review_id = p.cru_review_id AND p.cru_moderator = true limit 1) from cru_state_change);{code}

The nested query seems to be joining on itself {{cru_review_id = p.cru_review_id}}. 

Changing the statement to the following fixes it:

{code:sql}insert into new_cru_state_change (select cru_id, cru_time_stamp, cru_superseded, cru_review_id,cru_new_state,
  (SELECT p.cru_user FROM cru_review_participant p WHERE cs.cru_review_id = p.cru_review_id AND p.cru_moderator = true limit 1) from cru_state_change cs);{code}
fields.summary: Activity Stream produces incorrect results when upgrading from 1.6.x to 2.0.x

fields.description:
A user just asked me if it was possible to divide up a single review into subreviews.

I told him no, but he had some interesting ideas so I figure - might as well pass them along.

What he wanted was to be able to review all the changes and to be able to either:
- mark a block of changed code as OK, or
- assign that block of code to someone else to review (presumably as a sub-review of the current review.)

I'll be the first to say that this does not sound simple, but that I can see that it would be useful very for dealing with big changes. (In this case, merging different development streams.)
fields.summary: Ability to partition a review into sub-reviews

fields.description:
There is a typo mistake in the email template when replied comment is added into the review. 

{noformat}
	from	user <abc@gmail.com>
to	abc@gmail.com
date	Thu, Oct 1, 2009 at 10:45 PM
subject	[CR-37] Comment: test email template
mailed-by	gmail.com
	
hide details 10:45 PM (10 minutes ago)
	
- Hide quoted text -

user Replied
re: revision file2.txt(see http://customwa-1428ae:8060/cru/CR-37#c450 ) :-

test 4

In reponse to thread:
(user) test 1
{noformat}

It should be 'In *response* to thread:' instead.
fields.summary: Typo mistake in the email template
Next/Previous comment button does not work consistently

fields.description: Very often Cru truncates a review title from a SVN commit comment and lops off the last word or two or five which I then need to fix. It happens almost every time I create a review which is annoying. I suggest Cru gets smarter about it - look for the first period or perhaps only truncate where the title will exceed the actual field length in the DB. And make that DB field length really long.
fields.summary: Be smarter when truncating review titles from SVN commit comments.

fields.description:
step to reproduce:

# make a review, add some revisions, and complete it so that it is in the summarize state
# click on each file and check that the source is not being shown
# click on the Pref menu - the 'show source' item is checked. Uncheck it

result: the source is shown when the pref item 'show source' unchecked (and clicking on it again resets it, so the problem goes away).

||initial||[!http://img.skitch.com/20091001-cyu528rne1446aa7cp4cjj4sjq.png|width=600!|http://skitch.com/chii/nbm1g/cr-fe-2417-crc-905-the-page-link-of-project-dashboard-is-not-available-summarize]||
||after clicking||[!http://img.skitch.com/20091001-qpuj1kftxphxihse87qt64ss7g.png|width=600!|http://skitch.com/chii/nbm1p/cr-fe-2417-crc-905-the-page-link-of-project-dashboard-is-not-available-summarize]||
fields.summary: a review in the summarize state hides the source, but the pref menu still has show source checked

fields.description:
this plugin is currently not bundled with cruc, let's make it so.

a bug to fix before 2.1 goes out is that closed/abandoned reviews should NOT be included in any of the review lists.

another improvement is to remove the hard coded reference to the "in review" status.  Ideally a customer could select the jira status that corresponds to an issue being in review.
fields.summary: Bundle JIRA blocker report and fix bug re closed bugs

fields.description:
When you go 
1 Select 'Edit Review'
2 Select 'File'

There is one scroll bar for that screen but this is cumbersome as you navigate down a file structure because often you click through directories which ends up taking the scroll bar farther down than the last file in the current directory making it appear that there are no files in that directory until you scroll up. There should be a scroll bar for the directory navigation and a separate one for the directory contents.
fields.summary: Edit Review Pane Navigation Issues

fields.description:
Steps

1 Select 'Edit Review'
2 Select 'Review Content'
3 Select file with red dot next to it
4 Select newer revision of file
5 Select 'Add'

you get this error

Error:
Cannot perform requested action

Note that line-based comments for FakeDirectory/Blah/FakeFile.cs may no longer display correctly because the revisions have been updated. FakeDirectory/Blah/FakeFile.cs 96734 is already included in this review. FakeDirectory/Blah/FakeFile.cs 94958 is already included in this review. Updated FakeDirectory/Blah/FakeFile.cs, now contains

then 

6 Select 'Reload' on error dialog (you can also cancel)
7 Select FakeFile.cs again
8 Select newer revision
9 Select 'Add'
10 Updates file for review to use newer revision

This doesn't happen every time but it happens quite a lot and is very frustrating when a bunch of files have changed.
fields.summary: Adding Newer Revision for a File in 'Review Content' Pane in 'Edit Review' Screen Regularly Throws an Error
